docs.snippet: Americans watched 253,652 years worth of videos last month. And you wonder why you feel like you got nothing done?...
docs.lead_paragraph: Although Google's purchase of YouTube hasn't paid of financially, it has clearly made Google a giant in the world of online video, displaying more than 13 billion videos during the month of April.

docs.lead_paragraph: On the heels of the Kno, a tablet for the college market, Dell introduced its own take on the tablet on Wednesday. The Streak, a 5-inch touchscreen device, had made appearances earlier at Google's developer conference, but it received a fuller introduction at D8, The Wall Street Journal's technology conference on Wednesday.

docs.snippet: At a technology conference, Mr. Jobs pours cold water on rumors that Apple will do away with Google's search products or that it will soon revamp its ailing Apple TV product....
docs.lead_paragraph: For Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple, the timing of his public appearance at the D8 conference could not have been better. Last week, Apple surpassed Microsoft to become the world's most valuable technology company. A little more than a decade ago, Apple was struggling for its life, and many tech pundits were predicting its demise.

headline.main: Steve Jobs Muses on All Things Apple

docs.abstract: At a technology conference, Mr. Jobs pours cold water on rumors that Apple will do away with Google's search products or that it will soon revamp its ailing Apple TV product.

docs.snippet: Getting Google to directly deliver the information you want to see....
docs.lead_paragraph: If you don't want to spend all your time trawling the Web for updates on your favorite topics, have Google deliver the latest articles directly to your e-mailbox. Just create a Google Alert, which is a message full of links to current news articles, video clips and other sources concerning your subject. Visit Google's alert page, and in the search box, type in the topic you're interested in, say, "New Orleans Saints." Pick the types of sources you want to draw from, as well as the frequency and number of results you'd like to see. Fill in your e-mail address and click the Create Alert button to stop chasing the latest information and have it come to you.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: A Google Delivery

docs.abstract: Getting Google to directly deliver the information you want to see.

docs.snippet: Need to speak to a business and don't know the number? Just send a text and you're connected....
docs.lead_paragraph: Google's GOOG411 service popularized a way for people to get business phone numbers for free, instead of paying up to $2.00 to get a phone number from a wireless or landline carrier. You just dial 800-GOOG411, and voice prompts ask for the name and city of the business, and the business name. When found, the voice recites the number, and either dials it for you or sends you the number and address as a text message.

headline.main: No Talking Required for These 411 Calls

docs.abstract: Need to speak to a business and don't know the number? Just send a text and you're connected.

docs.snippet: BUSINESS DAY     An article on Friday about Google's decision to surrender to European governments the personal data it improperly collected over unsecured wireless networks erroneously included one country among those to receive the data. Google ...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUSINESS DAY An article on Friday about Google's decision to surrender to European governments the personal data it improperly collected over unsecured wireless networks erroneously included one country among those to receive the data. Google will share the data with regulators in Germany, Spain and France -- but not with regulators in Italy.

docs.snippet: Keeping up with the World Cup online....
docs.lead_paragraph: The World Cup starts today and soccer fans can keep up on all the latest results with a variety of free desktop widgets, gadgets and browser add-ons. For example, the Fédération Internationale de Football Association, the group that governs international soccer, has a page of World Cup widgets to deliver tournament news right to one's blog, Facebook, MySpace or iGoogle page. FootieFox, an add-on for the Firefox browser, is another option for quietly checking the scores at work.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Enjoying the World Cup

docs.abstract: Keeping up with the World Cup online.

About 40 people, all gathered in Mountain View, Calif. at a NASA campus for a nine-day, $15,000 course at Singularity University, saw it happen, The New York Times's Ashlee Vance writes.

docs.snippet: Microsoft will release its new version of its office suite, Office 2010, on Tuesday. Microsoft Office, which encompasses the workplace staples Word, Excel and Outlook, has dominated sales this year, along with iWork, the Apple productivity applica...
docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft will release its new version of its office suite, Office 2010, on Tuesday. Microsoft Office, which encompasses the workplace staples Word, Excel and Outlook, has dominated sales this year, along with iWork, the Apple productivity application that is compatible with Word and Excel documents. Office 2010 tweaks its core products and introduces Web Apps, online versions of Word, Excel (above), OneNote and PowerPoint. These will compete with an application that is not on the top sellers list because it is free: Google Docs, the so-called cloud computing productivity programs that users can reach from any computer. Office 2010 users will be able to store documents online, giving them universal access, too. SHELLY FREIERMAN

headline.main: Popular Demand

docs.snippet: The war of words between Google and Apple over mobile ads sharpened on Wednesday.     AdMob, the mobile advertising start-up that Google recently acquired, said Apple's new terms of service for the iPhone 4 and iPad, if enforced, would prevent it ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The war of words between Google and Apple over mobile ads sharpened on Wednesday. AdMob, the mobile advertising start-up that Google recently acquired, said Apple's new terms of service for the iPhone 4 and iPad, if enforced, would prevent it from putting ads inside mobile apps. That could be crippling for AdMob, which is the No. 1 seller of ads in iPhone apps. Omar Hamoui, the chief executive of AdMob, said the policy could hurt developers too.

headline.main: AdMob Fears Being Excluded From iPhone

docs.abstract: Bits blog reports Google's AdMob says Apple's new terms of service for iPhone 4 and iPad, if enforced, would prevent it from putting ads inside mobile apps; photo (S)

docs.snippet: The online shrine to Brazilian beefcake now comes in oversize print form....
docs.lead_paragraph: Things just got a little easier for modelizers, who have exhausted Google, YouTube, The Fashionisto, Hero, et al. Made in Brazil is the latest guilty pleasure for dedicated fans of the male modeling industry. This shrine to Brazilian beefcake, which was previously only available online, now comes in oversize print form, and features 96 uninterrupted pages of runway regulars and new editorial faces. Evandro Soldati graces the cover; inside, fellow veteran Romulo Pires - a modeling Methuselah at 27 - wrestles with pups, while up-and-comers Francisco Lachowski and Max Motta play demon and angel - scantily-clad, of course.

headline.main: Model Boys From Brazil

docs.abstract: The online shrine to Brazilian beefcake now comes in oversize print form.

byline.contributor: Brad Stone reported from San Francisco and David Barboza from Shanghai.
byline.original: By BRAD STONE  and DAVID BARBOZA

docs.snippet: SAN FRANCISCO -- Google plans to stop automatically sending users in mainland Chinese to its uncensored Hong Kong site, in an effort to appease Beijing as it seeks to renew its license to operate in China.     The action, experts on China say, amo...
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO -- Google plans to stop automatically sending users in mainland Chinese to its uncensored Hong Kong site, in an effort to appease Beijing as it seeks to renew its license to operate in China. The action, experts on China say, amounts to a symbolic gesture that Google hopes will placate the Chinese government, which may be feeling pressure from citizens who are demanding continued access to Google's search engine.

headline.main: Google Takes Step To Placate China

docs.abstract: Google plans to stop practice of automatically sending users in mainland China to its uncensored Hong Kong site in effort to appease Beijing as it seeks to renew its operating license there; symbolic gesture may placate Chinese government at time when its citizens are pressuring it to allow access to Google's search engine; Google began routing internet traffic to google.com.hk after it said it could no longer justify filtering its search results to meet government requirements; photo (M)

byline.original: By BRAD STONE  and DAVID BARBOZA; Brad Stone reported from San Francisco and David Barboza from Shanghai
